answer: Cross-site scripting (XSS) is an injection attack that allows attackers to inject client-side scripts into web pages viewed by other users. Types: reflected, stored, DOM-based. Prevention: output encoding, Content Security Policy (CSP), input validation, and proper use of HTTPOnly and SameSite cookies.

Cross-site request forgery (CSRF) tricks a user's browser into performing actions on another site where they're authenticated. Defenses: anti-CSRF tokens, SameSite cookies, and checking Origin/Referer headers.

The ls -la command lists directory contents in long format and shows hidden files. Flags: -l long listing (permissions, owner, size, mtime), -a include dotfiles. Useful combos: ls -lah (human-readable sizes).
